abstract.p: Article suggests using wildflowers in fall gardens (S)

block.p: If your fall garden seemed uninspiring this year, think about organizing its colors the way Mother Nature does. In the fall, country fields are full of Queen Anne's lace, wild asters and blue chicory, all sprouting cheek by jowl with brilliant yellow goldenrod. Waves of gold make a wondrous backdrop for the starry clumps of blue and white.

If your fall garden seemed uninspiring this year, think about organizing its colors the way Mother Nature does. In the fall, country fields are full of Queen Anne's lace, wild asters and blue chicory, all sprouting cheek by jowl with brilliant yellow goldenrod. Waves of gold make a wondrous backdrop for the starry clumps of blue and white.

Chicory and Queen Anne's lace are too weedy for most gardens, but asters, especially the New England type, are readily available. Plant some white-flowering boltonia (Boltonia asteroides) for contrast. Add goldenrod (Solidago). Contrary to popular belief, it won't make you sneeze. If you have the space, plant the asters, boltonia and goldenrod in swathes. Next year at this time your garden will look like a little piece of the autumn countryside.
